newsitem.title: CAMBODIA: Taiwanese accused of arms role in Cambodia.
newsitem.headline: Taiwanese accused of arms role in Cambodia.

text.p: Cambodia's Second Prime Minister Hun Sen on Monday accused unidentified Taiwanese, including a general, of involvement in this month's fighting in Phnom Penh, prompting sharp denials from Taipei.
"A group of Taiwanese mafia arrived in Cambodia. The day there was fighting happening, the Taiwanese were there," he said in a speech to villagers in Kompong Thom province north of the capital.
Hun Sen was referring to fighting in Phnom Penh on July 5 and 6 when he ousted First Prime Minister Prince Norodom Ranariddh.
"Frankly speaking there was a two-star general there. Now he is hiding in Phnom Penh. We have evidence these Taiwanese gave money to buy weapons," he said. "I accuse the Taiwanese completely."
Hun Sen said Cambodia could cooperate with Thailand and Vietnam to arrest the Taiwanese people. He did not elaborate.
Taiwan's foreign ministry on Monday denied any government involvement.
"The government will not involve itself in the internal politics of any foreign country," Taiwan Foreign Ministry spokesman Roy Wu told reporters in Taipei.
Taiwan's defence ministry denied the presence of the two-star general. "There was absolutely no such thing," it said.
An official at Taiwan's trade office in Phnom Penh, which represents the Taiwan government in Cambodia, said he was not aware that any Taiwan people were involved in Cambodia's political crisis.
"We have never heard of that. We don't do things like that," said the official who declined to be identified.
Cambodia follows a one-China policy, recognising Beijing and not Taiwan, although Taiwan is Cambodia's largest foreign investor.
China has considered Taiwan a rebel province since the end of the Chinese civil war in 1949.
